race.name: SBT GRVL
race.tagline: Champagne gravel at altitude - where the pros come to play and the views will make you forget about the suffering

distances.name: BLACK
distances.description: Elite race course with rolling enclosure - the flagship event

distances.name: BLUE
distances.description: Substantial ride course with significant climbing

distances.name: RED
distances.description: Mid-distance option balancing challenge and accessibility

race.terrain: Famous 'champagne gravel' - smooth, high-quality gravel roads through working ranches, aspen groves, and sage-studded hills at high altitude
race.weather: High-altitude Colorado summer - cool mornings (40s-50s¬∞F), warm afternoons (70s-80s¬∞F), potential afternoon thunderstorms. Unpredictable mountain weather.

logistics.explanation: Yampa Valley Regional Airport offers direct flights from 12 cities, and Denver is a 3-hour drive. Registration sells out via lottery with no race day packet pickup. Ben Brown describes the opening chaos: "The first hour was fucked... 900 people spread out across the road, all jockeying to get to the front. There was a crash right next to me on the first rise."

length.explanation: Black course at 108 miles demands serious strategy and endurance. Ben Brown faced the reality at mile 40: "Matt and I made a pact that we wouldn't go too hard given that there was still 100 miles to go." Bruce Lin's ambitious goal required shaving an hour off his previous 8:58:13 finish to break 8 hours on the full distance.

technicality.explanation: Mixed terrain includes champagne gravel plus technical challenges. Ben Brown encountered "thick, loose gravel on a downhill... like riding through sand at a cyclocross race... except you're going like 40mph and surrounded by other people and the sand is rocks." The course includes an unexpected singletrack section and hay field CX detour.

elevation.explanation: The 8,189 feet of climbing includes serious sustained efforts. Ben Brown described the mile 40 climb as "a 4-mile, 9%, gravel situation that goes from 6.5k to around 9.5k." Even with conservative pacing on the major climbs, riders face significant elevation challenges throughout the Rocky Mountain terrain.

climate.explanation: Late June Colorado conditions proved challenging for riders. Libby Brown reported "hot and dry" conditions during the race, severe enough that she required IV treatment for dehydration after Friday's course recon. Pre-race weather included "sheets of rain pummeled the roof of the car" for travelers reaching Colorado.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 6,700 feet and climbing to ~8,500 feet puts this firmly in high-altitude territory. Riders from sea level will feel the thin air significantly - acclimatization is strongly recommended. Higher altitude racing, comparable to Atlas Mountain Race.

adventure.explanation: The route through working ranches and champagne gravel roads delivers iconic Rocky Mountain terrain. After the first major climb, riders traverse "a long section of bare plateau, which was beautiful" before hitting singletrack sections. The famous Cow Creek descent caps the adventure with "the roughest descent on the course" featuring rocks, ruts, and livestock.

prestige.explanation: One of the crown jewels of gravel cycling. Independent event founded by Amy Charity in 2019, attracts world-class pros (Keegan Swenson's three-peat, Lauren De Crescenzo, Lauren Stephens) despite not being part of any major series. Iconic status on its own merit.

race_quality.explanation: Professional production includes rolling enclosure, well-stocked aid stations, and detailed course warnings about dangerous sections. The lottery system and no race-day pickup demonstrate serious organization. Mechanical support appears at critical points - one rider's valve core issue was "fixed on the spot" by a course mechanic at mile 120.

experience.explanation: From Yampa Street staging through champagne gravel to working ranch country, riders encounter bucket-list terrain. The progression includes 30-mile gravel sectors, "impromptu CX" through hay fields, and singletrack covered in "thick, powdery dust" before the infamous final descent creates an unforgettable Rocky Mountain pilgrimage.

community.explanation: Founded with equal prize money and strong inclusivity focus. Sydney Marshburn noted that "adding a para category to a large event like SBT GRVL showed the world that cycling is for everyone." Over 40 para-athletes attended in 2022, with Andrew Bernstein finishing first paracyclist and 18th overall in his distance.

field_depth.explanation: Elite competition attracts world-class pros despite independent status. The opening hour intensity demonstrates the caliber: Ben Brown's group power "was barely lower than it would be in a 75-minute crit" just to stay connected. Keegan Swenson's early attacks and three consecutive wins showcase the elite racing standard.

value.explanation: At $275 for most courses, it's premium pricing that reflects the production quality and iconic status. Bruce Lin invested in proper hotel accommodation over camping: "I'm way too soft" for basic sleeping setups before major efforts. The lottery entry system and destination nature justify costs for most participants.

expenses.explanation: Total costs escalate beyond the $275 registration in resort town Steamboat Springs. Bruce Lin specifically upgraded from camping to hotel accommodation due to comfort concerns. Libby Brown required IV treatment after course recon, highlighting potential medical costs. Remote location and summer lodging rates create significant barriers.

uniqueCharacteristics: World-famous 'champagne gravel' - the smoothest, fastest gravel roads on Earth
Independent event attracting world's best gravel racers through prestige alone
Founded by Amy Charity with equal prize purses since 2019
Routes through working Colorado ranches and stunning mountain scenery
Four course options from 25-108 miles for all abilities
Steamboat Springs ranked #3 Best Small Towns in USA
Estimated $4.5 million economic impact - one of the world's largest gravel events
race.popularity: Very High - one of the most prestigious gravel events in the world

final_verdict.one_liner: Champagne gravel at altitude with a three-day festival vibe that somehow doesn't ruin the racing.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you can hold 20+ mph for five hours at 7,000 feet, the Black course rewards fitness with buttery gravel and legitimate competition. The 8 mph cutoff sounds generous until you're grinding into headwinds at altitude. Come undertrained and you'll get pulled to a shorter course, which isn't the worst fate given the scenery.
final_verdict.alternatives: Unbound 200 offers more prestige and suffering if you want the hardest test. Big Sugar delivers similar smooth gravel without the altitude penalty, while Dirty Kanza's spiritual successor BWR California gives you desert beauty with less lottery drama.

course_description.character: SBT GRVL serves up 108 miles of Colorado's famous 'champagne gravel' - smooth, fast surfaces that seduce you into thinking this will be easy. The 8,189 feet of climbing happens gradually across working ranch land, aspen groves, and sage-covered hills, with 70% gravel that ranges from hero dirt to loose chunky sections that'll humble your bike handling.

suffering_zones.label: The First Cutoff
suffering_zones.desc: Miss the 8:30 AM cutoff here and you're redirected to the Blue Course. The champagne gravel has already started sorting the field on rolling ranch roads.

suffering_zones.label: The Second Sort
suffering_zones.desc: Another cutoff point where dreams get redirected. You're deep enough into the sage hills that the smooth gravel has given way to chunkier, more technical surfaces.

suffering_zones.label: The Aspen Grind
suffering_zones.desc: Deep into ranch country where the cumulative elevation starts compounding your suffering. The gravel stays fast but your legs don't.

suffering_zones.label: The Reality Check
suffering_zones.desc: Twenty-three miles from home with most of the climbing behind you, but the champagne gravel has turned your legs to concrete. The math gets brutal here.

course_description.signature_challenge: The thing nobody tells you about SBT GRVL: champagne gravel is fast until it isn't. The deceptively smooth surfaces let you burn matches early while the altitude and relentless rolling terrain compound every tactical mistake. By mile 80, that silky gravel feels like riding through wet cement, and you've got 28 miles to contemplate your pacing choices.
course_description.ridewithgps_name: Black Race Course | SBT GRVL¬Æ p/b Wahoo 2026

citations.label: RideWithGPS: Black Race Course | SBT GRVL¬Æ p/b Wahoo 2026
theproscloset.com: My Race Plan For Sbt Grvl 2023
trainright.com: Reggie Miller Sbt Gravel 100 Mile Gravel Race
outsideonline.com: E Bike Paracycling Sbt Grvl Andrew Bernstein

key_takeaways: Keegan Swenson: Three consecutive wins (2022-2024), set and broke course records

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: SBT GRVL gravel race Steamboat Springs

videos.title: SBT GRVL 2025: Relive the Epic Steamboat Gravel Race | Highlights, Pro Wins & Community Spirit
videos.description:
The 2025 SBT GRVL p/b Wahoo ride routes showcase the rural scenic beauty of remote regions of Routt County as we take riders on sections that they‚Äôll find familiar from past years, as well as on entirely new sections that have been previously untouched by GRVL prior to 2024.

videos.curation_reason: Recent 2025 race recap with excellent production quality featuring first-person race experiences and specific course details about the champagne gravel.

videos.title: SBT GRVL¬Æ 2025 Recap
videos.description:
SBT GRVL¬Æ p/b Wahoo is more than a ride or a race; it's a 4 day celebration of cycling that spills from Yampa street in downtown Steamboat Springs, and flows onto the champagne gravel roads of Routt County. 

Join us as we relive all of the action of June 26-29th, from Wahoo Dunk Tanks to our infamous Canyon HLL CLMB, breakfast in the park, yoga, toddler races, Saturday ride, and the grand finale; our Sunday Pro and amateur race where first time racers took to our Black Course for age group podiums and bragging rights, while top gravel pros battled it out for the top step and their share of the $22,000 prize purse and signature Stetson.

sponsors for making this entire weekend
possible. We couldn't do it without you,
and we look forward to seeing you again
in June 2026.
videos.curation_reason: Official 2025 race recap showcasing the full 4-day event experience and community atmosphere.

videos.title: ‚Äã‚ÄãCan Manon Survive A 225km US Gravel Race? | SBT GRVL
videos.description:
Manon has been training hard for her biggest ever challenge: taking on the SBT GRVL race in Steamboat Springs, Colorado. The race is at altitude and, at 142 miles (224km) in length, with 9,200 feet (2800m) of climbing, it will be Manon‚Äôs longest ever ride. This challenge will be far from easy! Will Manon be able to survive this epic US gravel race?

In association with @RibbleCyclesChannel üëâ https://gcn.eu/Ribble

The Global Cycling Network (GCN) is the largest online cycling channel in the world, bringing together a global community of road cyclists to celebrate everything that‚Äôs great about the world of cycling.

Our videos bring fans compelling daily content including expert tutorials, techniques, training, racing, cutting-edge bike tech, unparalleled behind the scenes event coverage, humour,  entertainment, and more.

Presented by ex-pro riders, GCN offers a uniquely qualified insight into the world of cycling, and most importantly it‚Äôs fuelled by our passionate and enthusiastic fans ‚Äì everyone who makes up the GCN community. We also bring the latest and greatest tech to your attention, showcase the best places in the world to ride and get exclusive access to events and races.

videos.curation_reason: High-quality first-person race experience from major cycling channel with detailed course challenges and altitude struggles.

videos.title: 2019 SBT GRVL - Steamboat Gravel Pro Race
videos.description:
Excerpts from SBT GRVL, front of the pro race onboard with yours truly. Various clips before we were all seeing double later in the day! Thanks for a great course and awesome event!

http://AllenKrughoff.com

videos.title: SBT GRVL 2024 Black Course - not my best day, but worth a pedal
videos.description:
Traveled to Steamboat Springs from Jax Bch for my first SBTGRVL BLCK, left Jax on Friday AM and came back Monday AM allowing my body ‚Äò0‚Äô acclimatization.

Organization, people, activities, town, farmer‚Äôs market, race fair/shindig, HLLCLMB, yoga class, volunteers, local restaurants, locals, etc, etc were superb.
My black course race not so much. In fact, the black course did me.
Rode my TopStone Cannondale, knobby 40mm w/ tubes, ate/drank INFINIT nutrition stuff (use code: gavelmauve) and LMNT to get salty and less crampy.
I regret not going to one of the multiple, willing, mechanics that would have taken 15 minutes to tune up my bike after flying in a hard case. They were available all day Friday and Saturday and I did not take advantage of it. Furthermore, during the race each Aid Station and a few other random places sprinkled in between all had mechanics that I, again, passed on. Not sure why, but in an effort to finish faster, I delayed my arrival.
I had a few mechanicals during the race: flat, not proper shifting, brakes rubbing (realized after finish), but had a great experience in rural CO.
First 20 miles to the 1st Aid were smooth. They felt a little tough, maybe the altitude or maybe the brakes but was able to make good time. After the station in the Wahooligan pass I had my first flat, lost my riding partners and the wheels came off shortly after.
Getting to the 37 and 67miles station was tough, but was able to join a small group of about 3-4 and we kept each other company to the halfway station in Hayden.
The toughest 25 miles were after the Hayden Station, the wind was strong from the SE and for the next 25 miles we headed mostly SE and uphill too. During mile 80ish I had to stop, get in the fetal position, puke, question my life choices again, and somehow talk myself out of quitting. (this is the part when I think about explaining to my kids, wife, fam in general and social media).
After the puke and the last bit of uphill, again some race volunteer in a van was just there. Just there waiting for me!!! I really hope he understands that his words and proper description of the miles ahead gave me the hope and encouragement I needed. Sat in his van ate something drank a nasty warm coke and continued.
The mental F**k of this race is that once you enter the ‚Äòchampagne‚Äô you do not leave it basically for 110 miles. It all looks beautiful, but it looks the same for a long time. (Does have a ‚ÄòSouthern Spain‚Äô feel to it. Just south of their Sierra Nevada.)
The last 20/30 miles of the course are ‚Äòearned‚Äô, you could say they make you suffer at the front end so that you enjoy some downhills and (defntly planned :wink: ) tail winds. The last two aid stations were nice. One had a teepee to chill for a minute and get shade, both were fully staffed and stocked, I needed mostly ice and got it.
The ride into town was fast, the tarmac and the tail winds helped.
After my arrival, shower and the award ceremony I volunteered folding the barricade signs and breaking up a bit. Went to the room, packed the bike, slept 3 hours and headed to the airport.

Will prob do again, very differently, next year.

quotes.text: Historically, Steamboat Gravel with its champagne gravel is a fast course. It's just this fine little pebbles or the bubbles in champagne. It's fast. It's so fast.
Gravel racing in steamboat feels insanely fast. Every gravel race is so so hard. The altitude's a beast.
I knew it was going to be dusty strong gravel but literally after that first gravel section I was covered in dust, my bike was filthy.

key_challenges.name: First Gravel Section
key_challenges.description: Immediately after neutral section ends, course becomes extremely dusty. Riders report being covered in dust and bikes becoming filthy after just the first gravel section.

key_challenges.name: Single Track Section
key_challenges.description: Very bumpy and fun section described as almost like a cyclocross race before returning to smooth tarmac.

key_challenges.name: Five Mile Climb
key_challenges.description: Described as a 1,000 foot climb which riders note as bigger than most have done before. Steep climbs throughout the course challenge even fast gravel climbers.

key_challenges.name: Washboardy Downhill
key_challenges.description: Technical downhill section with washboard surface where excited riders pass frequently, described as scary by some participants.

terrain_notes.text: The champagne gravel is described as fine little pebbles like bubbles in champagne. It's fast, so fast, making Steamboat Gravel historically a fast course.
Course becomes extremely dusty immediately after the first gravel section. Riders report being covered in dust and bikes becoming completely filthy very early in the race.

gear_mentions.text: Rider used Ribble Gravel SL with carbon frame, noting all components are completely changeable so you can adjust stem or handlebar sizes unlike other brands where you get what you're given.

race_day_tips.text: Better to ride your own pace rather than trying to stay with a group pushing out of your comfort zone. Slow and steady definitely wins the race in this case.
Start out slow and just see how the day comes. See how you feel. You need to keep checking in with yourself because sometimes you can forget how far you have to go.
Pack as much food as possible in back pockets. One rider reported physically not being able to fit any more food in their pockets before the race.

additional_quotes.text: Three months and two days ago I threw my name into the hat to try and ride the steamboat gravel race in the heart of the rockies and it wasn't just any of the four loops that you could choose from but the longest one 224 kilometer gravel loop

SBT gravel is an event that takes place over 4 days. So, the first two days are an expo. Saturday is our ride day with three course distances: blue course 100 miles, red course 55 miles, and green course 37 miles. Sunday we have our race for both amateurs and professionals.

rider_intel.search_text: SBT Gravel in Steamboat Springs features the famous champagne gravel - fine pebbles that create an extremely fast racing surface. The course becomes intensely dusty immediately after the first gravel section, covering riders and bikes completely. Key challenges include a grueling five-mile, 1,000-foot climb that tests even elite gravel climbers, technical single track sections resembling cyclocross, and scary washboard downhills where excited riders frequently pass. The altitude makes racing feel insanely fast and presents a significant challenge. The event spans four days with expo activities, multiple course distances from 37 to 100+ miles, and attracts 1,800+ riders from all backgrounds. Riders emphasize pacing strategy over group riding, recommending starting slow and checking in with yourself throughout the long distance. The course plays to different strengths with 90% favoring certain rider types, but steep climbs require conservative pacing and altitude management.

Gravel cyclists at aid station refueling with support crew in rural Colorado mountain setting - SBT GRVL - Steamboat Springs, Colorado
